Council Delays Vote
The Student Council, this week,
reconsidered the issue of Viet Nam
and decided that although the
Council was authorized to make
a stand on the war, it would postpone its decision until after the results of TIME, Inc.'s Choice '68
poll were announced.
The issue on whether the Council should take a stand was calmly
dealt with, in marked contrast
with last week's stormy session.
In the March 4 meeting, representatives Borow and Bozarth left the
meeting to prevent the Council
from drafting a statement.
This week, the Council followed Bill Betcher's recommendation
that the decision be delayed until
after the Choice '68 Poll. This was
the viewpoint expressed by Dean
Rudoy at the previous meeting.
Postponement of the decision
will give the Council a better indication of students' views on the
war. The results of the Council
poll of February indicated that the
students were against present policy. The returns from that sampling, however, included only a
third of the undergraduate body.
It was generally felt that a
statement at this time could not
hope to represent the feelings of
all of the students. It is expected
that a greater number of students

will respond to the Choice '68
poll.
In other Council business, Russ
Passarella presented the answers
of various U.S. Senators to the
Council's letter which protested
the drafting of college graduate
students. Among those answering
the letter were Senators Dirksen
(R -- Illinois) and Tydings (D-Maryland). The Council will hold
open meetings to air the campus'
views on the question of graduate
deferments. The views of the
Council will be. published in the
News-Letter.
The Council also endorsed a
committee report on the dormitories presented by Russ Passarella.
Among the improvements called
for were the formation of a review
board composed of the DSRC and
the Housemasters, and the extention of girl privileges to vacation
periods
Finally, a discussion on the financially troubled VECTOR was
held. Vector Editor Charles Polnitzky traced the course of the
publication's finances and stated
that he and the staff were not at
fault. The Council supported continuance of the publication and requested that it be given needed
funds.

Douglas Supports Federal Funding of Candidates
"There is once again an uneasy
feeling among the public that legislators are corrupt, that our democratic processes are tainted with
fraud and that the whole political
structure of our country is decadent," said the Honorable Paul H.
Douglas, ill a lecture here last
Thursday.
Mr. Douglas, who last year was
"forcibly retired," as he puts it,
after eighteen years in the Senate,
addressed a large audience in Slidvet Hall, on "Some Ethical Problems of National Legislators."
Not That Bad
Mr. Douglas began his talk with
the assurance that conditions in
Congress are "not nearly as bad as
most people believe." He said that
the Senate was a more ethical body
than it had ever been before. He
emphasized the fact that any Senator who did misuse funds was
driven to that remedy by the high
cost of holding political office. •
The first financial hurdle which
a candidate must face is the cost of
running for office. The Congress
has placed a limit on candidate expenditures. According to this measure, a candidate for the House

may spend only $5,000, a Senatorial candidate, $25,000 and a presidential candidate, $3 million.
According to Mr. Douglas, actual
costs may run to more than forty
times these estimates.
Never Heard Of It
This forces the candidate to
form separate "citizens' committees" and to obscure his expenditures by channelling money
through these groups. Then, the
candidate must disavow any knowledge of the existence of these
committees. Douglas added, "The
results are therefore demeaning as
well as ineffective. And yet almost
no practicing politician dares to
confess the truth."
Seven G's
The high cost of running for
office discourages many men from
lower and middle income groups.
The former Senator believes that
a new and democratic way of financing campaigns must be instituted. "Otherwise we will close
off public life to people and interests who need to feel that they
are a part of society and can make
contributions to it."
The second great problem

which tends to challenge the ethics
of our national legislators is that
of financing their stay in office.
Out of his salary as a Senator, of
$30,000, Douglas was left with
less than $7,000 after taxes and
expenses. This small sum had to

cover all of his and his family's
living costs. Douglas cautioned
about being too harsh on Thomas
Dodd, of Connecticut. Dodd had
to put six children through college
on roughly the same budget.
An increase in legislators' salaries is, however, not the answer.
Douglas believes that this would
only tend to up the cost of a stay
in office. He favors the solution
proposed by Senators Lee Metcalf
and Albert Gore. This proposal
calls for certificates of one dollar
to be distributed to every registered voter. The voter could then
give this certificate to the candidate, party, or political organization of his choice.
In this way, the high cost of
campaigning could be funded by
the federal government. But the
individual voter would also be able
to make a significant contribution
to the candidate he favors.

Johnsonian Democracy
If anything conclusive has resulted from the Senate Foreign Relations hearings last Monday and Tuesday, it is that all the potshots by
senators, congressmen and other "official" representatives will not
sway the present Administration from its murderous course in Viet
Nam. Lyndon.Johnson will not be shaken even if Senator McCarthy
runs up a string of primary victories, which is, in itself, doubtful. The
last three administrations covering the past fourteen years have made
covert and overt commitments to the tragedy which has manifested itself in Vietnam.The only attitude which has changed under the leadership of the past three presidents is an increase in the degree of executive arrogance.
As early as 1954, The United States under Eisenhower was paying
75% of France's cost in running the Indochinese war,(some of the
funds being siphoned off from the supposedly altruistic Marshall
Plaa). Kennedy formalized the American commitment in the 60's,
and Johnson has made our present course irrevocable. There should
be no misunderstanding - - this country's leadership has never doubted that the United States would intervene in Vietnam. Our presence
there was a planned and conscious move. The history of this involvement has also been a history of circumventing or ignoring protest.
In the fifties, the American people were,for the most part, unaware
of our building commitment in Asia. Now, in the sixties, Lyndon
Johnson uses the best of two methods: he denies rumors of any stepups in the war, only to escalate months later, or he arrogantly acts
despite outcries from "responsible" leaders.
"I do not excuse myself," said Senator Albert Gore at the hearings
Tuesday. "We all should have raised questions earlier." This is a sad
and costly admission - - the original sin of most of our legislators
However, perhaps Senator Gore is absolved by the fact that presidents like Lyndon Johnson have demonstrated that such questions
would not have made a difference in policy-making."As sure as I'm
sitting here," stated Senator Frank Church,"by fall, we'll have more
American soldiers in Vietnam that those of the Vietnamese." No
denial by Rusk. The policy of the Johnson administration has taken
on the air of inevitability. When questioned by senators opposing the
war,Rusk always replied with the classic "Well, we are going to .
This is the "we" of the Administration and it does not include the
elected representatives in the Senate and the House. Rusk's "we"
tells us that the McCarthys,Kennedys, Churchs and Morses are irrelevant. In effect, we are irrelevant. The administration has closed the
door on alternatives proposed by other parties. The only role of the
American citizen in the Johnsonian scheme is to pay for the war in
blood and in money.
Nor is Johnson, as the popular mythology goes, any more receptive to leaders concerned with domestic problems. That Johnson and
his Administration ignores notable educators, civil rights leaders,
economists and social reformers. Meantime, the news media decries
the growing alienation from the traditional political structure.
Most political observers have recently expressed hope in the McCarthy movement because it is encouraging dissenters to work
through the established order. Unhappily, this is wishful thinking, it
is an illusion. The answer - - the action which will make a dent in
Johnson's arrogance (taking into account the likely assumption that
he will be re-elected) - - is widespread resistance, particularly in regard to the War. Alternatives to Johnson lie in draft resistance,
refusal to pay war-connected taxes such as the federal levy on telephone bills, and in mass protests such as Martin Luther King's upcoming March on Washington. The system which Johnson represents
must be challenged since no other candidate or official on the political scene presently offers a viable alternative. This is not a new philosophy. It harks back to Thoreau and Rousseau who knew that citizens have the right to use extra-legal means when a government ceases to be responsive. Since Johnson is putting an end to dissent as the
cherished American tradition, we see no other way.

The Student Council, this week,
reconsidered the issue of Viet Nam

poll were announced.
The issue on whether the Council should take a stand was calmly
dealt with, in marked contrast
with last week's stormy session.
In the March 4 meeting, representatives Borow and Bozarth left the
meeting to prevent the Council
from drafting a statement.
This week, the Council followed Bill Betcher's recommendation
that the decision be delayed until
after the Choice '68 Poll. This was
the viewpoint expressed by Dean
Rudoy at the previous meeting.
Postponement of the decision
will give the Council a better indication of students' views on the
war. The results of the Council
poll of February indicated that the
students were against present policy. The returns from that sampling, however, included only a

statement at this time could not
hope to represent the feelings of
all of the students. It is expected
that a greater number of students

will respond to the Choice '68
poll.

deferments. The views of the

feeling among the public that legislators are corrupt, that our democratic processes are tainted with

Not That Bad

the assurance that conditions in

the Senate was a more ethical body

emphasized the fact that any Senator who did misuse funds was

The first financial hurdle which

running for office. The Congress
has placed a limit on candidate expenditures. According to this measure, a candidate for the House

may spend only $5,000, a Senatorial candidate, $25,000 and a presidential candidate, $3 million.
According to Mr. Douglas, actual
costs may run to more than forty
times these estimates.
Never Heard Of It

form separate "citizens' committees" and to obscure his expenditures by channelling money
through these groups. Then, the
candidate must disavow any knowledge of the existence of these
committees. Douglas added, "The
results are therefore demeaning as
well as ineffective. And yet almost
no practicing politician dares to
confess the truth."

The high cost of running for
office discourages many men from
lower and middle income groups.
The former Senator believes that
a new and democratic way of financing campaigns must be instituted. "Otherwise we will close
off public life to people and interests who need to feel that they
are a part of society and can make
contributions to it."
The second great problem

which tends to challenge the ethics
of our national legislators is that
of financing their stay in office.
Out of his salary as a Senator, of
$30,000, Douglas was left with
less than $7,000 after taxes and
expenses. This small sum had to

cover all of his and his family's
living costs. Douglas cautioned
about being too harsh on Thomas
Dodd, of Connecticut. Dodd had
to put six children through college
on roughly the same budget.

Douglas believes that this would
only tend to up the cost of a stay

and Albert Gore. This proposal

Johnsonian Democracy
If anything conclusive has resulted from the Senate Foreign Relations hearings last Monday and Tuesday, it is that all the potshots by
senators, congressmen and other "official" representatives will not
sway the present Administration from its murderous course in Viet
Nam. Lyndon.Johnson will not be shaken even if Senator McCarthy
runs up a string of primary victories, which is, in itself, doubtful. The
last three administrations covering the past fourteen years have made
covert and overt commitments to the tragedy which has manifested itself in Vietnam.The only attitude which has changed under the leadership of the past three presidents is an increase in the degree of executive arrogance.
As early as 1954, The United States under Eisenhower was paying
75% of France's cost in running the Indochinese war,(some of the
funds being siphoned off from the supposedly altruistic Marshall
Plaa). Kennedy formalized the American commitment in the 60's,
and Johnson has made our present course irrevocable. There should
be no misunderstanding - - this country's leadership has never doubted that the United States would intervene in Vietnam. Our presence
there was a planned and conscious move. The history of this involvement has also been a history of circumventing or ignoring protest.
In the fifties, the American people were,for the most part, unaware
of our building commitment in Asia. Now, in the sixties, Lyndon
Johnson uses the best of two methods: he denies rumors of any stepups in the war, only to escalate months later, or he arrogantly acts
despite outcries from "responsible" leaders.
"I do not excuse myself," said Senator Albert Gore at the hearings
Tuesday. "We all should have raised questions earlier." This is a sad
and costly admission - - the original sin of most of our legislators
However, perhaps Senator Gore is absolved by the fact that presidents like Lyndon Johnson have demonstrated that such questions
would not have made a difference in policy-making."As sure as I'm
sitting here," stated Senator Frank Church,"by fall, we'll have more
American soldiers in Vietnam that those of the Vietnamese." No
denial by Rusk. The policy of the Johnson administration has taken
on the air of inevitability. When questioned by senators opposing the
war,Rusk always replied with the classic "Well, we are going to .
This is the "we" of the Administration and it does not include the
elected representatives in the Senate and the House. Rusk's "we"
tells us that the McCarthys,Kennedys, Churchs and Morses are irrelevant. In effect, we are irrelevant. The administration has closed the
door on alternatives proposed by other parties. The only role of the
American citizen in the Johnsonian scheme is to pay for the war in
blood and in money.
Nor is Johnson, as the popular mythology goes, any more receptive to leaders concerned with domestic problems. That Johnson and
his Administration ignores notable educators, civil rights leaders,
economists and social reformers. Meantime, the news media decries
the growing alienation from the traditional political structure.
Most political observers have recently expressed hope in the McCarthy movement because it is encouraging dissenters to work
through the established order. Unhappily, this is wishful thinking, it
is an illusion. The answer - - the action which will make a dent in
Johnson's arrogance (taking into account the likely assumption that
he will be re-elected) - - is widespread resistance, particularly in regard to the War. Alternatives to Johnson lie in draft resistance,
refusal to pay war-connected taxes such as the federal levy on telephone bills, and in mass protests such as Martin Luther King's upcoming March on Washington. The system which Johnson represents
must be challenged since no other candidate or official on the political scene presently offers a viable alternative. This is not a new philosophy. It harks back to Thoreau and Rousseau who knew that citizens have the right to use extra-legal means when a government ceases to be responsive. Since Johnson is putting an end to dissent as the
cherished American tradition, we see no other way.
